body: This all sounds quite odd. A file is deleted when another device says that it has been deleted - which happens if we get a "does not exist" or other error when trying to scan the file on that side... Perhaps some sort of transient I/O error? But then I'd expect the files to come back when that recovers...

OK so I gave some more thought on that, stared a lot into journalctl (on Fedora) and here are my notes:
-  The "recent" milestone could have been the last boot, Tuesday afternoon. Most files that were preserved I'm sure I have edited after that. I remember editing gnucash data file soon  after boot to Fedora, and that file was preserved as well (too bad I did not save list of preserved files).
-  The laptop was suspended (systemctl suspend) at least two times since that.
-  The moment when things seem to go bad is: after resume from last suspend, on Sun 03:33, I updated and restarted the Fedora's syncthing using WUI.  The journalctl from that time looks like this:
  

Probably most scary are the "has mismatching index ID" messages.  Soon after that, things go bad: those paths mentioned in the "Puller" messages are already _partially_ gone. These "mismatching" messages also appear on VPS; although here they also appear few hours later with another v0.14.3 device, but data here did not get wiped.

Note that since that incident, the state is still Out Of Sync, due to 6 folders. Other than that, it appears to function normally. Apparently st has no way to resolve those partial deletes so I'm going to try and fix that manually later somehow (probably back up, make the folders empty, wait for them to disappear and restore).

So, all in all, the root cause is still unknown to me. I cannot rule out local fs failures (/home is on encrypted partition on lvm), although neither journalctl nor dmesg say anything, and most importantly, the system has been functioning normally, no other files disappeared, the 'st' folder is in no way special regarding local fs.

The mismatching index ID messages are a feature - they're part of the 0.14.3 -> 0.14.4 upgrade. From those logs it looks to me like `SI74UPV` is the device that sends the delete instructions. Anything interesting happen on that side?

But `SI74UPV` ignores most of the 'st' folder.  This is its `.stignore`:

```
!/bin
!/utils
*
```

But then again, I'm not sure, actually these could be also some of (old) files that were preserved unlike other old files. So maybe the `.stignore` is part of the case.

I have tried to put together logs from all three machines; hopefully I did not filter out too much:

0.14.4 [changed the way, invalid and ignored files are handled](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/3464). Maybe this change caused `SI74UPV` to send deletes for the ignored files?
It could be. If the files were at some point deleted on SI74UPV, _then_ ignored, and they are _not_ ignored on ZINNF57, that would probably make the deletes take effect now.

Yet the delete and the ignore should happen while the other side is disconnected, otherwise the delete would have been propagated immediately.

Also, this relies on the files never being modified too...

This makes a lot of sense; I know I haven't set up the machine properly on first try.  I don't remember exactly what I did, but it could be what @calmh writes above or very similar.

I actually even asked on irc:

```
Jul 21 04:11:01 <netvor> hi guys, have a noob q: 1. I shared a (big) folder to a newly configured device
Jul 21 04:11:41 <netvor> (but I actually wanted to sync only 1 subfolder, that's special to this dev)
Jul 21 04:12:00 <netvor> 2. so I rushed and added .stignore to avoid DLing whole folder
Jul 21 04:12:11 <netvor> 3. but I was too slow
Jul 21 04:13:47 <netvor> so 4. how do I safely delete things from the device?  I'm assuming that it's safe to delete everything that is ignored anyway... but how can I make sure?
Jul 21 04:24:13 <netvor> ok so turns out that my ignore is wrong :/ I'll just let it be for now
```

but finally hacked it and somehow made it work sooner than somebody could reply (who's up at 4am right? :)).

I doubt it, unfortunately. This is a suboptimal effect of files that were deleted and then ignored on one side, and then not ignored on the other, when moving past 0.14.4. We have a small majority of users on 0.14.4 already so the window for fixing this is shrinking.

One way to handle it properly might be to do a one time drop of everything ignored from the local index, when upgrading to 0.14.5 I guess?
Maybe we should always make sure to forget our local index entries for ignored files.

Hello, I had run into the same (not as "devastating") issue as Alois. 
The last suggestion describes behaviour I was expecting to happen instead independently on version.

I'm sorry about that.

Note though that for this to happen, you need to already be on 0.14.0 through 0.14.3, delete some files and then ignore them, then join another device and resurrect the files somehow, then upgrade to 0.14.4+. As such I think this is quite rare, although obviously with quite damaging effects. I don't want to rush out a fix for this for tomorrows release, as we might introduce something scary in the process.

issue.title: Files in .stignore propagate deletions

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
I have a relatively large sync folder. I have a `Pictures` folder, which contains several GB of pictures. In my work laptop I sync this folder (and I use syncthing-inotify here). Since to work I do not need to look at my pictures, I decided to ignore the Pictures folder. My .stignore looks like this:

```
Pictures/

```

I then proceeded (as a test) to delete a couple of subfolders there. The deletion propagated to the other syncs. Luckily I have a NAS where I use file versioning so no data is lost. But this was very unexpected.

The logs from the receiving end looked like this (for all the subdir tree):

```
INFO: Puller (folder "felipe", dir "Pictures/Viejas/$subfolder"): delete: remove $base/Pictures/Viejas/$subfolder: directory not empty
```

Unfortunately I did not capture logs on the sending side.

I am not sure if syncthing-inotify is at fault for watching on ignored folders, but still syncthing should not propagate changes to ignored folders.
### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.14.4 (sender) v0.14.3 (receiver)
OS Version: Windows 7 (sender) / Debian sid (receiver)

Sender uses syncthing-inotify (installed via syncthing-gtk v0.9.1-win32).

body: Issue #3543 was closed as dup of this one. In my case, the files were deleted _after_ being ignored.
Ignoring files on device A doesn't prevent them from being deleted on device B unfortunately. I need to consider how this hangs together and potentially write something up about it...
